content.description: Step off a large wave battered boulder straight onto a crux with extremely difficult gear, climbing past a false crack. Take time to set it right, and it will still pull out the first few times. Who doesn’t like a good scare?
content.protection: Ball nuts, black Alien, blue metolius, a yellow mastercam and a yellow TCU

content.description:
After one or two moves of Infinite Abyss, make a crux traverse rightward to the glorious arete with a tricky barn-door sequence. Layback the LEFT side of the arete. DO NOT CROSS ONTO THE RIGHT SIDE of the arete. The left side is super safe, but if you get tempted onto the right side, you’ll shred your rope and die... The third bolt is far left to force you to stay completely on the left side, for your safety. If you get tempted to the right, you won't be able to clip it; theoretically preventing you from climbing the right side. (Do Not Climb The Right Side)

The FA was done on RBs, but it now has titanium!
content.protection: 5 bolts. Long slings needed for the anchor. Walk off.
content.location: Scramble around the Oceanside Boulder from the north, and land on a sharp fin of rock perched above the surf. Belay there. The leader may as well belay from the top.

content.description:
Those of us who noticed this line, all thought not much about this thing for years, but it turned out to be very, very good! At low tide, scramble around to to the base from the north, then belay perched on a small pinnacle, surrounded by waves. Stem across and make a few unprotected moves {edit: now protected by the first bolt for Motion In The Ocean} then on to quality laybacking over a thin crack. The route is alluded to as "#25 Crack" in the Bigfoot Guide, and it doesn't sound like it's been led. I'm glad I finally bothered to check it out, it was fantastic.

Another edit: a bit of minor cleaning unfortunately revealed a few good finger locks that dropped the grade from 11a.
content.protection: Plenty of small gear. The anchor is now two bolts. Bring long chord.
content.location: Circle counter clockwise around to the base.

content.description: At a very low tide, step off the tidepools onto left-trending rails to a leisurely, well-protected finish. The rope can stay coiled on the large boulder, dry.
content.protection: tiny tiny gear. There are now two bolts for an anchor, no more sketchy thin anchor.

content.description: Short overhanging arete leaning towards the Main Wall. Pretty neat moves, but short.
content.protection: 4 RBs. 2 bolt anchor 20' past the lip.
content.location: Southeast arete of the Oceanside Boulder.

content.description: Nice little wide crack, starts mellow, gets a bit steeper near the top. Some hand stacks really help in the crux.
content.protection: 3-5"  Anchor with big gear, or smaller gear hidden below the crack.
content.location: Just west, below the Puff Boulder. Scramble down from the north.
